item.title: Report X-2024070948
item.description:
Report X-2024070948

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-12
  • City: MIDDLETOWN
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Federal Express Corporation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Shipment taken out of system flow due to external carton wet. Upon inspection of inner contents 4 X 1 gallon plastic bottles of GLB Aqua Silk Chlorine-Free Shock Oxidizer. 1 X 1 gallon plastic bottle of shock oxidizer was cracked allowing 1 gallon to release. The other 3 X 1 gallon plastic bottles were not damaged. Each bottle was in its own plastic bag. No slotted partitions or absorbent was found. Facility procedures for damaged hazardous materials followed. Contents contained and awaiting disposition.

item.title: Report X-2024070959
item.description:
Report X-2024070959

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-11
  • City: RICHFIELD
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hazmat was found at door 125 in the load end ready to go to the next load point. The outbound sort manager walked passed it and noticed a very strong odor coming from the box. QA was contacted immediately to inspect the box. I noticed a little wet spot on one of the bottom corners of the package and brought it over to the office in a lined tote for further inspection. The inner drum seamed to have a poor quality closure that caused some of the contents to spill out and make it a little noticeable to the naked eye. Once the package was fully opened, the corrugated liner seamed to be wet also to confirm that the hazmat was damaged and could have possibly been damaged while it was on the vehicle when the driver returned from the pick up but could have dried do to the Acetone & Isopropyl Alcohol ingredient that makes up the product.

  • Description: Package was damp on the bottom, brought to qa by a manager for inspection. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the gallon jugs were packed upside down relative to the orientation arrows on the outer packaging. This led to slow internal leakages from the caps of the jugs. Spill was contained by the outer packaging. Package was placed into a salvage drum with gloves and is awaiting disposition.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: DURING THE UNLOAD THE MANAGER NOTICED THAT THE METAL PAIL HAD A DENT BASICALLY ON THE TOP EDGE WHICH WAS CAUSING LIQUID TO LEAK FROM THE PAIL. MANAGER IMMEDIATELY TOOK THE PAIL TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE AND VENTILATE IT PROPERLY. I WAS THEN CALLED OVER TO REPACK IT INTO A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER. APPROXIMATELY 1 LITER LEAKED FROM THE TOP CLOSURE DUE TO A DENT AND PUNCTURE AT THE TOP. WAITING FOR THE DISPOSITION FROM PGH NOW.

ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 3 pounds of product released to a 4' x 4' area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. The damaged bag, released product, and PPE were collected into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024070030
item.description:
Report E-2024070030

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-01
  • City: SOUTH GATE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: J. B. HUNT TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 3ft-by-5ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that thirty (30) gallons of material was released due to four (4) crushed 5-gallon plastic pails. The damaged plastic pails were placed into one (1) 30-gallon and one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. Clean Harbors personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted area and then used a granular absorbent to gather the spent material. The contractor placed the recovered spent absorbents into one (1) 30-gallon poly drum. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum was generated containing impacted pallet pieces. One (1) additional 15-gallon poly drum was generated for the contractors PPE. All waste generated from this response was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for J.B. Hunt contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070218
item.description:
Report E-2024070218

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-01
  • City: MENOMONEE FALLS
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee was offloading pallets of drums from a trailer at Veolia's 1- day intransit facility in Menomonee Falls, WI. In the process of offloading the trailer, the forks on the forklift extended past the end of the pallet due to it being a smaller size pallet. The employee was unaware of their surroundings and length of forks, allowing the forks to puncture a drum loaded in the truck behind the pallet that was being offloaded. Approximately 1/2 of a gallon of material leaked before the employee was able to secure the drum from leaking any further. The duration of the spill was approximately 30 seconds. The material was then cleaned and the employees reported the spill of material. The drum that was damaged with the forklift was overpacked for safe transportation to the disposal facility.

Upon inspection by BNSF responder, one swing bolt was loose and down, while the other 5 were less than tool-tight. The manway was opened, gasket inspected and manway lid secured properly.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9400
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The KAG Energy, LLC driver was delivering diesel fuel into the customer's storage tank. During the course of the delivery, the connection between the hose adaptor and storage tank became compromised. This caused approximately 100 gallons of diesel fuel to be released. A portion of the spilled diesel fuel was able to impact a nearby storm drain. Hepaco Environmental responded to the scene and handled the remediation.

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-09
  • City: BARRINGTON
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: DURING THE UNLOAD THE MANAGER NOTICED THAT THE PACKAGE WAS LEAKING AND ALSO WAS WET ALL OVER THE BOTTOM OF THE PACKAGE. IT WAS IMMEDIATELY TAKEN OVER TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE IT AND VENTILATE IT. I WAS THEN CALLED OVER TO REPACK IT INTO A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER. APPROXIMATELY 10 LITERS LEAKED OUT ALTOGETHER FROM THE 4 BOTTLES ON THE INSIDE OF THE PACKAGE. ONE BOTTLE HAS A PUNCTURE AND THE OTHER 3 BOTTLES HAD LOOSE CAPS WHICH IS WHY IT WAS LEAKING IN THE FIRST PLACE. WAITING FOR THE DISPOSITION FROM PGH NOW.

It seems the shipper may have been trying to ship under 49 CFR 173.13, but they did not include the statement on the box that it was covered under exception 49 CFR 173.13, so I cannot confirm this.

item.title: Report E-2024070201
item.description:
Report E-2024070201

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-12T15:12:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-08
  • City: N VERSAILLES
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Stephen Hudspeth
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 8th 2024, at approximately 11:30am, Union Railroad Train 50a was in the process of entering the Port Perry and Dexter Yards with a 96 car loaded iron ore train. The train was led my four locomotives. Brakes were applied to the locomotives only and allowed to release on the remainder of the train. This caused a great deal of force in the train that allowed the cars to leave the track. Rail dislodged during the derailment impacted the fuel tank of the third from lead locomotive causing it to spill its contents of fuel. Three of the four locomotives derailed as well as five of the 96 loaded ore cars. No other material was spilled, the remaining locomotives had no leaks. Internal responders were notified and responded to the derailment. The spill response plan was followed alerting the required agencies. A derailment contractor was called in to re-rail the train, and internal forces were assembled to repair the track. The liquid product on the ground was collected as quickly as possible into buckets, however most of the product entered the ballast and surrounding soil. The nearby river was monitored for signs of a sheen, inlets were checked but it was found the fuel had not reached either. A spill contractor was dispatched to provide lined dumpsters for the contaminated soil. The contractor also provided a vacuum truck to clean up the track area that could not be reached with an excavator. Contaminated soil was placed in the lined dumpsters. Dumpsters are staged for pickup when manifests are created and samples are analyzed. The area of the spill will be restored with new ballast. Any recovered fuel will be filtered and re-used elsewhere on the railroad. The locomotive with the broken fuel tank was checked in the morning and recorded to have about 900 gallons of fuel before the trip. 40 gallons were recovered from the tank before re-railing the locomotive. The maximum amount spilled would be approximately 860 gallons, however some of that amount was likely used in transit between the start of duty and the derailment.

The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freights contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report X-2024070309
item.description:
Report X-2024070309

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-12T15:12:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-02
  • City: SOUTH ELGIN
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 6
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ABF states city driver Rafael Zawadzki (00933020) called safety at 08:15PM (CDT) about a hazmat spill that was not reported earlier in the day or cleaned by CURA. ABF driver stated that a bottle of UN2789, ACETIC ACID GLACIAL, 8 (3) PG II had spilled on the floor of trailer 401322 this morning. ABF driver stated that he began to feel lightheaded, nausea, shortness of breath, and headaches throughout the day he was delivering with the trailer. ABF driver states once he arrived back to ABF113, he notified Safety about the spill and his symptoms got worse. ABF driver reported his symptoms to Rodney Cooper (Operation Supervisor) and Rodney also stated he felt those same symptoms. ABF states during the call with Mr. Cooper, he informed Safety that his 4 other workers at that time (Rafael Zawadzki, Jason Granderson, James Fortin, and Joe Keefer) had also experienced these same symptoms. ABF Safety advised that at all costs, stay away from trailer 401322 until CURA had serviced it. ABF Safety immediately notified hazmat on-call at 08:43PM about the situation and on-call stated to do a spill report like normal and call CURA out to the scene ASAP. ABF Safety called CURA at 08:57PM and CURA dispatched a team to the location arriving at 10:26PM. ABF SCM Joshua Sabolcik states that they took one employee to Ascension Saint Joseph - Elgin Hospital (847-695-3200) and his 4 other workers to Advocate Sherman Hospital (847-742-9800) in Elgin, IL for treatment.

  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 2, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN1760 arrived on its side and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews uprighted the fallen tote, inspected it, and remediated it as required. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, cleaners, and absorbents to remediate the site. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 35-gallon drum to be staged onsite for future disposal.

  • City: ARCOLA

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) quart of material released from one (1) 1-gallon metal pail. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area and placed the recovered material and damaged pail into one (1) 6-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freights contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070184
item.description:
Report E-2024070184

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-12T15:12:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-25
  • City: MANSFIELD
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: EnviroServe was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 6ft-by-8ft area of the trailer floor and 1ft-by-5ft area of the asphalt lot and estimated that three (3) gallons of material was released due to damage on two (2) 55-gallon metal drums. EnviroServe personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and gathered the spent absorbents and placed them into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum along with impacted cardboard. The two 92) damaged drums were overpacked into one (1) 85-gallon metal drum and one (1) 85-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: UTLX 910980 was found by a carman during an inspection to have an odor of "propane". Local FD was notified and the immediate area of the leaking car was evacuated. FD arrived along with contractor Republic Services. Entry was made and Republic found a loose plug on the vapor valve and the vapor valve was opened about 1/4 turn. The valve was closed and the plug was taped and tool-tightened, mitigating the release.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: UNDECLARED HAZMAT PACKAGE CAME FROM UNLOAD TORN, WET, CRUSHED AND LEAKING. PACKAGE DAMAGED IN TRANSIT, TOO MUCH WEIGHT ON PACKAGE AND INDADEQUATE BLOCK AND BRACE. NO MARKINGS INDICATING SHIPPING STATUS OF GOODS NOR USE OF ORIENTATION ARROWS. PREVIOUSLY DPR'D WITHOUT KNOWLEDGE THAT GOODS ARE REGULATED. SAFETY DATA SHEET CONFIRMS THAT GOODS ARE REGULATED. TWO BOTTLES CRUSHED, LEAKAGE FROM CAPS, ALL GOODS SOILED. SPILL COLLECTED WITH ABSORBENT MATERIALS, PACKAGE PLACED IN HAZMAT BAG LINED TOTE.

item.description:

  • City: FORT WORTH

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package was found on a cart next to the conveyor belt coming from unload. Box was ripped wide open and had wet spots. Upon inspection, all 4 of the 5 liter plastic bottles were full and no active leakage was found. However, 2 of the bottles were lightly soiled and had small drops of moisture on the outside, which tested as a pH 10-12, the same as the liquid inside. This suggests that prior leakage, although minor, occured.

The two bottles that had ethanolamine, were found leaking from the bottom of the bottle. Seem as though there was no inner packing inside the package to protect the product. Being placed in a red bin and being held at the station. More pictures provided for additional information.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-11T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-28
  • City: AZUSA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee brought a trailer to the unloading dock at Veolia's ten day intransit facility in Azusa, CA and staged it for unloading. While transferring pallets containing drums of hazardous waste, one of the 5 gallon drums was noticed to have a small indentation towards the bottom that created a pinhole. This pinhole had material slowly dripping onto the pallet. Approximately a few drops came out from the pinhole. The liquid was cleaned up with an absorbent rag. The 5 gallon drum was overpacked into a new drum for shipment. The actual material leaking was mineral oil which was used to stabilize the lithium. These drums were palletized and some drums may have been sticking outside of the parameters of the pallet which may have hit the trailer walls during the offloading process.

item.description:

  • City: WEST DEPTFORD

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On June 28, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1738 was punctured and released approximately fifteen (15) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel placed the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 95-gallon overpack. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the impacted pavement and trailer floor and swept them in with hand tools. Two (2) 55-gallon drums of spent absorbents and any cleanup debris were generated as waste.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-28
  • City: FREMONT
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee was moving drums into a trailer utilizing a drum grabber/clamp at Veolia's ten day intransit facility in Fremont, CA. The drum grabber/clamp gets a hold on the drum from the top and bottom portion of the drum lip. When picking up the next row of 55 gal metal drums, the employee tilted the mast back. Before driving forward, the employee noticed a liquid stream coming down on the side of one of the drums. Approximately 8 oz of the chemical was spilled and landed on the warehouse concrete floor. The spill did not enter any drains and was immediately cleaned up. The leaking drum was placed into a salvage container. There was no evidence of punctures or deficiencies to the drum itself.

item.title: Report X-2024070481
item.description:
Report X-2024070481

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-11T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-17
  • City: SAN BERNARDINO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: BURLINGTON NORTHERN RAILROAD HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 3000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 6/17/2024, the BNSF San Bernardino hub personnel reported Unit JBHU 262270 (Waybill Hazardous) as leaking a substance from the rear of the container that did reach the ground after unit was de ramped from a train. Unit was taken to the Hazmat Pit for safety. On the behalf of the shipper, approved contractor United Pumping was contacted and dispatched to complete inspection. Interior inspection revealed 15 supersacks in 2 rows throughout the container. Source of the leak was determined to be one supersack filled with pool chlorine granules in the rear of the unit. The cause for the Leak was determined to be less than a pound of pool chlorine leaked from the top of the supersack, contributing to the material leak. The granules mixed with the condensation in the unit creating a liquid which leaked from the rear of the container. Total quantity of leaked liquid was approximately 16 ounces of product. During the inspection a bullboard was located at the rear of the load as securement. Contractor United Pumping completed remediation of the unit and all affected areas. Spilled product was cleaned and disposed of.

item.title: Report X-2024070645
item.description:
Report X-2024070645

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-11T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-10
  • City: Proctor
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wisconsin Central Railroad Ltd.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 17086
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 2024/06/10 a CN transportation & mechanical employees observed liquid coming from the top and running down the sides of tank car # UTLX 212116 at the CN Proctor Yard in Proctor, MN. While performing switching operations. The on shift CN Transportation supervisor made all internal notifications to activate an emergency response to investigate the cause and perform a cleanup. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location and found the manway swing bolts were or appeared to be over tightened and compromised the lid gasket, pinching it and preventing a proper seal of the gasket allowing the contents to leak out when the car moved. Both the liquid and vapor line valve securement plugs were installed properly tool tight. The BOV cap was found tool tight. All the shipper security seals were found to be intact at the time of inspection. The security seals were removed from the manway cover and the protective housing cover on UTLX 212116. The manway lid was opened to inspect the lid gasket which was found to be pinched/crushed. The damaged manway lid gasket was removed and replaced with a compatible lid gasket, then the manway cover was closed, and all swing bolts were properly tightened. The valve securement plugs were inspected and found tool tight. As well the BOV cap was found secured tool tight and new security seals were applied to the manway as well as the combination housing. The exterior of the tank car was cleaned off utilizing a rags and absorbent pads. Once car was cleaned car was released back to transportation to continue to destination.

item.title: Report I-2024070007
item.description:
Report I-2024070007

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-11T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-30
  • City: Anchorage
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: Sterling Airways
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 29th, 2024, Sterling Airways accepted cargo to be moved from ANC to DUT(AWB 359-10000196). When accepting the shipment the ANC based employee asked the shipper if there was any dangerous goods in the shipment. The shipper stated that the package did not contain any dangerous goods. Based on this information, the shipment was accepted by Sterling and placed in storage until the next available flight to DUT. On May 30th, 2024, this shipment was transported on VC1101 to DUT around 8:30am. The next day, as part of the Manager of Ground Operations Standards normal processes, she reviewed the airway bill and discovered that there was a laptop in the description section of the airway bill. All airway bills currently are reviewed no later than the next day by Manager A. The review process of all airway bills was put into place due to cargo being a new process to the airline. The continued monitoring of airway bills is to ensure everything is done correctly. When the Manager of Ground Operations Standards discovered the laptop in the description section, she notified the Anchorage Station Manager of this discovery. The Station Manager then contacted the agent who was involved in creating this airway bill, and verified that there was in fact a laptop transported. Both the Manager of Ground Operations Standards and the Anchorage Station Manager verified that this should not have been transported due to the possibility of a lithium battery in the laptop, as described in section 1.2.C in the Cargo Acceptance Handbook which prohibits transport of lithium batteries. This event was immediately brought to the leadership's attention and notification was sent out to all managers and cargo agents and an investigation was opened.

item.title: Report E-2024070147
item.description:
Report E-2024070147

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-10T18:16:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-06
  • City: Brewster
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: John Vergis
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The WLE Brewster Yard Car Inspector found tank car PROX 44241 leaking from the bottom outlet valve. He called the Brewster Yardmaster who then called myself, John Vergis, Hazardous Materials Officer for the WLE. I came out to look at the car and found that the bottom outlet valve of the car was indeed leaking through the valve cap. The valve handle was in the closed position and would not close any more. It was a disengaging ball valve. I removed the seal from the valve handle #1880761 and the valve stem #1880762, so that I could try to cycle the valve to see if I could get the leak to stop. I could not get the valve to move in either direction either with the valve handle or with a pipe wrench directly on the valve stem. I tried to tighten the valve cap with a 36" pipe wrench but I could not get it any more tight and the leak would not stop. I put containment under the leaking valve and called Specialized Professional Services out of Washington , PA to come out to transload the car into another rail car. They arrived about 2300 hrs. to transload and completed the transload about 0600 the next morning. On Monday, 7-8-2024, SPSI came back out to clean the interior of the car so that it could go back to the MarkWest plant in Jewett to be repaired. After it was cleaned, I removed the bottom outlet cap and with a 36" pipe wrench, and a second person, we were able to get the valve to open. I looked up into the valve and saw that the nylon seal on the ball was shredded which was the cause of the leak.

  • Description: 1. X-2024070418 attachment Name:download (10).png 2. X-2024070419 A tugger brought over the package and placed it on the hazmat pallet in QA. At first glance, I could see the "HAZ" on the shipping label, but the packaging is a corrugated box with no dot or OP-900. Upon inspecting the package, I noticed a few wet spots on the inside of the box. All bottles had vented caps and leaked during transit. No orientation arrows on the box to ensure the safety of the contents and there were no packing materials as well.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-10T18:16:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-03
  • City: OAK PARK
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Federal Express Corporation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The shipper shipped a box containing three laptops and six tablets, all of which still had their Li-Ion batteries installed, without placing either a Class 9 diamond label or UN3481 Li-Ion battery sticker on the outside of the box. One of the cells in the Li-Ion battery of one of the laptops started generating a current, despite the laptop being powered off. This resulted in a buildup of heat sufficient to melt the malfunctioning battery cell, part of the laptop case, and some of the bubble wrap surrounding the laptop. It also gave off smoke and an unpleasant odor.

item.title: Report X-2024070468
item.description:
Report X-2024070468

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-10T18:16:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-10
  • City: Proctor
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wisconsin Central Railroad Ltd.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 17000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 2024/06/10 a CN transportation & mechanical employees observed liquid coming from the top and running down the sides of tank car # UTLX 204748 at the CN Proctor Yard in Proctor, MN. While performing switching operations. The on shift CN Transportation supervisor made all internal notifications to activate an emergency response to investigate the cause and perform a cleanup. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location and found tank car UTLX 204748 with (3) of the (6) manway cover swing bolts to be loose (could turn by hand), preventing a proper seal of the gasket allowing the contents to leak out when the car moved. Both the liquid and vapor line valve securement plugs were installed properly tool tight. The BOV cap was found tool tight. All the shipper security seals were found to be intact at the time of inspection. The security seals were removed from the manway cover and the protective housing cover. The manway cover was opened to inspect the gasket which was found to be in good condition. The manway cover was closed, and all swing bolts were properly tightened. The valve securement plugs were inspected and found tool tight. As well the BOV cap was found secured tool tight and new security seals were applied to the manway as well as the combination housing. The exterior of the tank car was cleaned off utilizing a rags and absorbent pads. Once car was cleaned car was released back to transportation to continue to destination

item.description:
Report E-2024070113

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-10T18:16:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-07
  • City: West Chester
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: A. DUIE PYLE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: While unloading freight from trailer material handler discovered a drum that was slightly leaking from the bottom. Further investigation revealed that a binder clip that was holding the paperwork for the drum had wedged itself between the drum and the pallet the drum was staged on and during the course of transportation the drum shifted and hut the binder clip which consequently slightly punctured the drum contributing to the unintentional release. Spilled material was neutralized and cleaned with absorbent and placed into a recovery container as was the punctured drum.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-09T15:13:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-29
  • City: San Francisco
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Halfway through the flight, passenger 20A, HOLUB/ALEXEIDAVID, told FA Pang that their laptop was emitting an electrical smell. FA conferred with FM and both agreed there was a smell. No flames, heat, or smoke were present. Out of an abundance of caution, the MacBook Pro was placed into the TCB. The TCB was placed in an aft Iav and monitored occasionally per CA instructions occasionally throughout the flight. The TCB remained in the aft Iav until descent, in which it was brought to the forward Iav for easy access upon door opening. Due to no signs of fire, smoke, or heat, pax was escorted to the exit and was able to retrieve the laptop out of the TCB. FAs reminded to fill out IORs and thanked for erring on the side of caution. Name: Alex Eidavid Holub Address: 36 Mayflower Drive Wenham MA 01984 Phone: 626-676-1736 Email: alexholub@gmail.com

item.title: Report I-2024070036
item.description:
Report I-2024070036

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-09T15:13:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-22
  • City: Charlotte
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES GROUP INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During offloading of the flight a mobility aid scooter arced with a flash and smoke when placed on the cargoveyor outside the aircraft cargo compartment. Upon opening of the battery compartment for the lithium ion battery, it was discovered that it was not the battery but one of the wires in the wire bundle had been pinched in the 2 halves of the battery housing leading to abrasion and a short circuit of the wire. There was some soot and evidence of burning where the wire came into contact with the metal frame of the scooter. There was no thermal runaway of the lithium ion battery although there could have been had the short continued.
